As its title suggests, Aaron Betsky and Erik Adigard's new book, ''Architecture Must Burn'' (Gingko Press, $39.95), is a radical call to arms to supplant the conventional built environments of today with more ephemeral structures. While the book's medium (Day-Glo graphics and wide-measure type) may seem to overpower its message, the content rises to the challenge.

Mr. Betsky, the curator of design, architecture and digital projects at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, and Mr. Adigard, a digital imaging guru, suggest that the world of bits and bytes can inspire architects. Mr. Betsky believes in sprawl as the physical manifestation of modernity and also advocates the sensuality of translucency. Mr. Adigard favors 12-color printing. While it's easy to be dismissive of the book's trendy, self-conscious design, the volume provokes on levels both aesthetic and intellectual -- often in maddening ways.
